metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Array Methods
Basic Array Methods

content.html:
Array length
Array toString()
Array at()
Array join()
Array pop()
Array push()

See Also:

Search Methods
Sort Methods
Iteration Methods 		Array shift()
Array unshift()
Array delete()
Array concat()
Array copyWithin()
Array flat()
Array splice()
Array toSpliced()
Array slice()

content.text: JavaScript Array length
The length property returns the length (size) of an array:
content.html: The length property returns the length (size) of an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let size = fruits.length;

content.text: JavaScript Array toString()
The JavaScript method toString() converts an array to a string of (comma separated) array values.
content.html: The JavaScript method toString() converts an array to a string of (comma separated) array values.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.toString();

content.text: JavaScript Array at()
ES2022 intoduced the array method at() :
content.html: ES2022 intoduced the array method at():

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits.at(2);

content.text: The at() method returns an indexed element from an array.
content.html: The at() method returns an indexed element from an array.

content.text: The at() method returns the same as [] .
content.html: The at() method returns the same as [].

content.text: The at() method is supported in all modern browsers since March 2022:
content.html: The at() method is supported in all modern browsers since March 2022:

content.code_html:
Chrome 92 Edge 92 Firefox 90 Safari 15.4 Opera 78
Apr 2021 Jul 2021 Jul 2021 Mar 2022 Aug 2021

content.text: Note
Many languages allow negative bracket indexing like [-1] to access elements from the end of an object / array / string.
content.html: Many languages allow negative bracket indexing like [-1] to access elements from the end of an object / array / string.

content.text: This is not possible in JavaScript, because [] is used for accessing both arrays and objects. obj[-1] refers to the value of key -1, not to the last property of the object.
content.html: This is not possible in JavaScript, because [] is used for accessing both arrays and objects. obj[-1] refers to the value of key -1, not to the last property of the object.

content.text: The at() method was introduced in ES2022 to solve this problem.
content.html: The at() method was introduced in ES2022 to solve this problem.

content.text: JavaScript Array join()
The join() method also joins all array elements into a string.
content.html: The join() method also joins all array elements into a string.

content.text: It behaves just like toString() , but in addition you can specify the separator:
content.html: It behaves just like toString(), but in addition you can specify the separator:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.join(" * ");

content.text: Popping and Pushing
When you work with arrays, it is easy to remove elements and add new elements.
content.html: When you work with arrays, it is easy to remove elements and add new elements.

content.text: This is what popping and pushing is:
content.html: This is what popping and pushing is:

content.text: Popping items out of an array, or pushing items into an array.
content.html: Popping items out of an array, or pushing items into an array.

content.text: JavaScript Array pop()
The pop() method removes the last element from an array:
content.html: The pop() method removes the last element from an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.pop();

content.text: The pop() method returns the value that was "popped out":
content.html: The pop() method returns the value that was "popped out":

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits.pop();

content.text: JavaScript Array push()
The push() method adds a new element to an array (at the end):
content.html: The push() method adds a new element to an array (at the end):

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.push("Kiwi");

content.text: The push() method returns the new array length:
content.html: The push() method returns the new array length:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let length = fruits.push("Kiwi");

content.text: Shifting Elements
Shifting is equivalent to popping, but working on the first element instead of the last.
content.html: Shifting is equivalent to popping, but working on the first element instead of the last.

content.text: JavaScript Array shift()
The shift() method removes the first array element and "shifts" all other elements to a lower index.
content.html: The shift() method removes the first array element and "shifts" all other elements to a lower index.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.shift();

content.text: The shift() method returns the value that was "shifted out":
content.html: The shift() method returns the value that was "shifted out":

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits.shift();

content.text: JavaScript Array unshift()
The unshift() method adds a new element to an array (at the beginning), and "unshifts" older elements:
content.html: The unshift() method adds a new element to an array (at the beginning), and "unshifts" older elements:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.unshift("Lemon");

content.text: The unshift() method returns the new array length:
content.html: The unshift() method returns the new array length:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.unshift("Lemon");

content.text: Changing Elements
Array elements are accessed using their index number :
content.html: Array elements are accessed using their index number:

content.text: Array indexes start with 0:
content.html: Array indexes start with 0:

content.text: [0] is the first array element [1] is the second [2] is the third ...
content.html:
[0] is the first array element
[1] is the second
[2] is the third ...

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits[0] = "Kiwi";

content.text: JavaScript Array length
The length property provides an easy way to append a new element to an array:
content.html: The length property provides an easy way to append a new element to an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits[fruits.length] = "Kiwi";

content.text: JavaScript Array delete()
Warning !
Using delete() leaves undefined holes in the array.
content.html: Using delete() leaves undefined holes in the array.

content.text: Use pop() or shift() instead.
content.html: Use pop() or shift() instead.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
delete fruits[0];

content.text: Merging Arrays (Concatenating)
In programming languages, concatenation means joining strings end-to-end.
content.html: In programming languages, concatenation means joining strings end-to-end.

content.text: Concatenation "snow" and "ball" gives "snowball".
content.html: Concatenation "snow" and "ball" gives "snowball".

content.text: Concatenating arrays means joining arrays end-to-end.
content.html: Concatenating arrays means joining arrays end-to-end.

content.text: JavaScript Array concat()
The concat() method creates a new array by merging (concatenating) existing arrays:
content.html: The concat() method creates a new array by merging (concatenating) existing arrays:

content.code_html:
const myGirls = ["Cecilie", "Lone"];
const myBoys = ["Emil", "Tobias", "Linus"];

const myChildren = myGirls.concat(myBoys);

content.text: Note
The concat() method does not change the existing arrays. It always returns a new array.
content.html: The concat() method does not change the existing arrays. It always returns a new array.

content.text: The concat() method can take any number of array arguments.
content.html: The concat() method can take any number of array arguments.

content.code_html:
const arr1 = ["Cecilie", "Lone"];
const arr2 = ["Emil", "Tobias", "Linus"];
const arr3 = ["Robin", "Morgan"];
const myChildren = arr1.concat(arr2, arr3);

content.text: The concat() method can also take strings as arguments:
content.html: The concat() method can also take strings as arguments:

content.code_html:
const arr1 = ["Emil", "Tobias", "Linus"];
const myChildren = arr1.concat("Peter");

content.text: Array copyWithin()
The copyWithin() method copies array elements to another position in an array:
content.html: The copyWithin() method copies array elements to another position in an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.copyWithin(2, 0);

content.text: Note
The copyWithin() method overwrites the existing values.
content.html: The copyWithin() method overwrites the existing values.

content.text: The copyWithin() method does not add items to the array.
content.html: The copyWithin() method does not add items to the array.

content.text: The copyWithin() method does not change the length of the array.
content.html: The copyWithin() method does not change the length of the array.

content.text: Flattening an Array
Flattening an array is the process of reducing the dimensionality of an array.
content.html: Flattening an array is the process of reducing the dimensionality of an array.

content.text: Flattening is useful when you want to convert a multi-dimensional array into a one-dimensional array.
content.html: Flattening is useful when you want to convert a multi-dimensional array into a one-dimensional array.

content.text: JavaScript Array flat()
ES2019 Introduced the Array flat() method.
content.html: ES2019 Introduced the Array flat() method.

content.text: The flat() method creates a new array with sub-array elements concatenated to a specified depth.
content.html: The flat() method creates a new array with sub-array elements concatenated to a specified depth.

content.code_html:
const myArr = [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]];
const newArr = myArr.flat();

content.text: Browser Support
JavaScript Array flat() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript Array flat() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 69 Edge 79 Firefox 62 Safari 12 Opera 56
Sep 2018 Jan 2020 Sep 2018 Sep 2018 Sep 2018

content.text: JavaScript Array flatMap()
ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2019 added the Array flatMap() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.
content.html: The flatMap() method first maps all elements of an array and then creates a new array by flattening the array.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.code:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.code_html:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const myArr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const newArr = myArr.flatMap(x => [x, x * 10]);

content.text: Browser Support
JavaScript Array flatMap() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:
content.html: JavaScript Array flatMap() is supported in all modern browsers since January 2020:

content.code_html:
Chrome 69 Edge 79 Firefox 62 Safari 12 Opera 56
Sep 2018 Jan 2020 Sep 2018 Sep 2018 Sep 2018

content.text: Splicing and Slicing Arrays
The splice() method adds new items to an array.
content.html: The splice() method adds new items to an array.

content.text: The slice() method slices out a piece of an array.
content.html: The slice() method slices out a piece of an array.

content.text: JavaScript Array splice()
The splice() method can be used to add new items to an array:
content.html: The splice() method can be used to add new items to an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.splice(2, 0, "Lemon", "Kiwi");

content.text: The first parameter (2) defines the position where new elements should be added (spliced in).
content.html: The first parameter (2) defines the position where new elements should be added (spliced in).

content.text: The second parameter (0) defines how many elements should be removed .
content.html: The second parameter (0) defines how many elements should be removed.

content.text: The rest of the parameters ("Lemon" , "Kiwi") define the new elements to be added .
content.html: The rest of the parameters ("Lemon" , "Kiwi") define the new elements to be added.

content.text: The splice() method returns an array with the deleted items:
content.html: The splice() method returns an array with the deleted items:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.splice(2, 2, "Lemon", "Kiwi");

content.text: Using splice() to Remove Elements
With clever parameter setting, you can use splice() to remove elements without leaving "holes" in the array:
content.html: With clever parameter setting, you can use splice() to remove elements without leaving "holes" in the array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.splice(0, 1);

content.text: The first parameter (0) defines the position where new elements should be added (spliced in).
content.html: The first parameter (0) defines the position where new elements should be added (spliced in).

content.text: The second parameter (1) defines how many elements should be removed .
content.html: The second parameter (1) defines how many elements should be removed.

content.text: The rest of the parameters are omitted. No new elements will be added.
content.html: The rest of the parameters are omitted. No new elements will be added.

content.text: JavaScript Array toSpliced()
ES2023 added the Array toSpliced() method as a safe way to splice an array without altering the original array.
content.html: ES2023 added the Array toSpliced() method as a safe way to splice an array without altering the original array.

content.text: The difference between the new toSpliced() method and the old splice() method is that the new method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the old method altered the original array.
content.html: The difference between the new toSpliced() method and the old splice() method is that the new method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the old method altered the original array.

content.code_html:
const months = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"];
const spliced = months.toSpliced(0, 1);

content.text: JavaScript Array slice()
The slice() method slices out a piece of an array into a new array:
content.html: The slice() method slices out a piece of an array into a new array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Lemon", "Apple", "Mango"];
const citrus = fruits.slice(1);

content.text: Note
The slice() method creates a new array.
content.html: The slice() method creates a new array.

content.text: The slice() method does not remove any elements from the source array.
content.html: The slice() method does not remove any elements from the source array.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Lemon", "Apple", "Mango"];
const citrus = fruits.slice(3);

content.text: The slice() method can take two arguments like slice(1, 3) .
content.html: The slice() method can take two arguments like slice(1, 3).

content.text: The method then selects elements from the start argument, and up to (but not including) the end argument.
content.html: The method then selects elements from the start argument, and up to (but not including) the end argument.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Lemon", "Apple", "Mango"];
const citrus = fruits.slice(1, 3);

content.text: If the end argument is omitted, like in the first examples, the slice() method slices out the rest of the array.
content.html: If the end argument is omitted, like in the first examples, the slice() method slices out the rest of the array.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Lemon", "Apple", "Mango"];
const citrus = fruits.slice(2);

content.text: Automatic toString()
JavaScript automatically converts an array to a comma separated string when a primitive value is expected.
content.html: JavaScript automatically converts an array to a comma separated string when a primitive value is expected.

content.text: This is always the case when you try to output an array.
content.html: This is always the case when you try to output an array.

content.text: These two examples will produce the same result:
content.html: These two examples will produce the same result:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.toString();

const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits;

content.text: Note
All JavaScript objects have a toString() method.
content.html: All JavaScript objects have a toString() method.

content.text: Searching Arrays
Searching arrays are covered in the next chapter of this tutorial.
content.html: Searching arrays are covered in the next chapter of this tutorial.

content.text: Sorting Arrays
Sorting arrays covers the methods used to sort arraysg.
content.html: Sorting arrays covers the methods used to sort arraysg.

content.text: Iterating Arrays
Iterating arrays covers methods that operate on all array elements.
content.html: Iterating arrays covers methods that operate on all array elements.

content.text: Complete Array Reference
For a complete Array reference, go to our:
content.html: For a complete Array reference, go to our:

content.text: Complete JavaScript Array Reference .
content.html: Complete JavaScript Array Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Array properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Array properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
After executing the following code: const fruits = ['Banana', 'Orange', 'Apple']; fruits.pop(); What will the fruits array look like?
content.html:
After executing the following code:
const fruits = ['Banana', 'Orange', 'Apple'];
fruits.pop();
What will the fruits array look like?

metadata.question: After executing the following code:const fruits = ['Banana', 'Orange', 'Apple'];fruits.pop();What will the fruits array look like?

content.question: After executing the following code:const fruits = ['Banana', 'Orange', 'Apple'];fruits.pop();What will the fruits array look like?
